qas.question: What was the name of the philosophy preached by Thomas Davidson?
What type of idealism was Thomas Davidson's philosophy?
According to Davidson, how many gods are there?
By whose philosophy was Davidson influenced?
What did Davidson believe the God of Aristotle is synonymous with?
What was Aristotle's pluralism based on?
How many Souls did Aristotle say there were?
Davidson's argument that God cannot exist apart from the world matched whose argument?
Apeirotheism was pluralistic idealism without what?
What did Davidson say God was antonymous to in Aristotle's works?

context: Thomas Davidson taught a philosophy called "<a0_0><b5_0>apeirotheism<b5_0/><a0_0/>", a "form of <a1_0>pluralistic<a1_0/> idealism...coupled with <b8_0>a stern ethical rigorism<b8_0/>" which he defined as "a theory of Gods <a2_0><b6_0>infinite<b6_0/><a2_0/> in number." The theory was indebted to Aristotle's pluralism and his concepts of Soul, the rational, living aspect of a living substance which cannot exist apart from the body because it is not a substance but an essence, and nous, <b9_0>rational thought<b9_0/>, reflection and understanding. Although a perennial source of controversy, <a3_0>Aristotle<a3_0/> arguably views the latter as both eternal and immaterial in nature, as exemplified in his theology of unmoved movers. Identifying Aristotle's God with <a4_0>rational thought<a4_0/>, Davidson argued, contrary to <b7_0>Aristotle<b7_0/>, that just as the soul cannot exist apart from the body, God cannot exist apart from the world.
